case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. General Manager, Assistant Manager and Secretary of Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 157 and 158 of 1957 and 5 of 1958 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 157 and 158 of 1957 and 5 of 1958. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1955,

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated October 31, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference Nos. 28, 29 and 30 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court, in Criminal Reference Nos. 28, 29 and 30 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated December 18, 1954,

facts.text: References arise out of judgment and order dated December 18, 1954, of the Sessions Judge, Deoria, in Criminal Revisions Nos. 7, 8 and 9 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated December 18, 1954, of the Sessions Judge, Deoria, in Criminal Revisions Nos. 7, 8 and 9 of 1954. C. Mathur, C. P. Lal and G. N. Dikshit, for the appellant. S. Barlingay and A. G. Ratnaparkhi, for the respondents. 1959. December 15.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 15, 1959 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. December 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-The question which falls to be determined in this group of appeals is whether field workers, i.e., Supervisors and Kamdars employed by a sugar factory

facts.text: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. owns a factory at Chhitauni for manufacturing sugar.

anchor.surface_text: The Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd.  hereinafter referred to as the companypany  owns a factory at Chhitauni for manufacturing sugar. The three respondents are respectively the General Manager, Assistant Manager and Secretary of the companypany.

facts.text: Three respondents are General Manager, Assistant Manager and Secretary of the company.

anchor.surface_text: The three respondents are respectively the General Manager, Assistant Manager and Secretary of the companypany. The companypany employs certain classes of field workers to guide, supervise and companytrol the growth and supply of sugarcane for use in the Factory.

facts.text: Company employs field workers (Supervisors and Kamdars) to guide, supervise and control the growth and supply of sugarcane for use in the factory.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany employs certain classes of field workers to guide, supervise and companytrol the growth and supply of sugarcane for use in the Factory. The Deputy Chief inspector of Shops and Commercial Establishment, Uttar Pradesh, filed three companyplaints against the respondents

facts.text: Deputy Chief Inspector of Shops and Commercial Establishment, Uttar Pradesh, filed three complaints against respondents in the court of Judicial Magistrate, Deoria.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Chief inspector of Shops and Commercial Establishment, Uttar Pradesh, filed three companyplaints against the respondents in the companyrt of the Judicial Magistrate, Deoria, charging them with companytravention of the provisions of ss. 12, 13 and 26 of the Act

facts.text: Complaints charge respondents with contravention of ss. 12, 13 and 26 of the Act in respect of field workers.

anchor.surface_text: charging them with companytravention of the provisions of ss. 12, 13 and 26 of the Act in respect of certain field workers employed by the companypany for - guiding, supervising and companytrolling the growth and supply of sugarcane.

facts.text: Respondents contended that the Act did not apply to field workers as they were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and exempt.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytended that the Act did number apply to those employees as they were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and accordingly exempt from the operation of the Act. The Judicial Magistrate rejected the companytention

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate rejected respondents' contention, convicted them of contravention of s. 26, sentenced each to fine of Rs. 30 in each of three cases.

anchor.surface_text: and companyvicted the respondents of companytravention of s. 26 of the Act and sentenced each of them to pay a fine of Rs. 30 in each of the three cases. Against the orders of companyviction and sentence, the respondents preferred revision applications

facts.text: Respondents preferred revision applications to Sessions Judge, Deoria.

anchor.surface_text: Against the orders of companyviction and sentence, the respondents preferred revision applications to the Court of Session at Deoria. The Sessions Judge disagreed with the view of the Trial Magistrate

facts.text: Sessions Judge disagreed with Trial Magistrate and referred cases to High Court recommending set aside of conviction orders.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge disagreed with the view of the Trial Magistrate and referred the cases to the High Court at Allahabad recommending that the orders of companyviction and sentence passed by the Trial Magistrate be set aside.

facts.text: High Court accepted references and acquitted respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the references and ordered that the respondents be acquitted. By the definition of a Commercial Establishment in s. 2 cl. 3 of the Act,

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh appealed to Supreme Court with special leave under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court at Allahabad took a companytrary view, and the State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this companyrt against the order of the High Court with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The United Provinces Shop and Commercial Establishment Act, 1947 was enacted

facts.text: Magistrate held field workers are employees of a Commercial Establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate who tried the respondents for offences under s. 27 of the Act held that the field workers were employees of a Commercial Establishment. The High Court at Allahabad took a companytrary view,

facts.text: High Court held field workers are not employees of Commercial Establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court at Allahabad took a companytrary view, and the State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this companyrt against the order of the High Court with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution. The United Provinces Shop and Commercial Establishment Act, 1947 was enacted to regulate the hours of employment

facts.text: Supreme Court held field workers are employees of Commercial Establishment as not employed in factory premises.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to hold that field workers who are employed in guiding, supervising and companytrolling the growth and supply of sugarcane to be used in the factory are employed either in the precincts of the factory or in the premises of the factory and if these workers are number employed in a factory,

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court acquittal and restored Magistrate's conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore in error in acquitting the respondents of the offences of which they were companyvicted by the Trial Magistrate. The orders of acquittal passed by the High Court are set aside and the orders of companyviction and sentence passed by the Trial Magistrate are restored.

facts.text: United Provinces Shop and Commercial Establishment Act, 1947 (Act XXII of 1947) regulates hours and conditions in shops and commercial establishments.

anchor.surface_text: The United Provinces Shop and Commercial Establishment Act, 1947 was enacted to regulate the hours of employment and certain other companyditions of employment in shops and companymercial establishments. Commercial Establishment is defined by s. 2, cl. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Complaints for contravention of ss.12 (weekly holiday), 13 (leave), 26 (registers) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 12 of the Act, provision is made for giving to the employees a weekly holiday besides holidays which may be granted under s. 11. Section 13 provides for granting, ordinary, casual and sickness leave. Section 26 requires the employer to maintain such registers and records

facts.text: Field workers are Supervisors and Kamdars.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined in this group of appeals is whether field workers, i.e., Supervisors and Kamdars employed by a sugar factory to guide, supervise and companytrol the growth and supply of sugarcane for use in the, sugar factory are employees of a Commercial Establishment

facts.text: High Court viewed Supervisors and Kamdars connected with subject of manufacturing process (sugarcane) as workers under Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the Supervisors and Kamdars companynected with the subject of manufacturing process, namely sugarcane, were workers within the meaning of the Factories Act and accordingly they were excluded from the definition of Commercial Establishment under the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court found field workers not employed in precincts or premises of the factory.

offences under s. 27 of the Act held that the field workers were employees of a Commercial Establishment. The High Court at Allahabad took a contrary view, and the State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this court against the order of the High Court with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Factories Act, 1948 defines a worker by s. 2  1  as meaning, a person employed, directly or through any agency, whether for wages or number, in any manufacturing process or in cleaning any part of the machinery or premises used for a manufacturing process, or in any other kind of work incidental to, or companynected with, the manufacturing process, or the subject of the manufacturing process.

holdings.text: even if the Supervisors and Kamdars were employed in any other kind of work connected with the subject of manufacturing process, unless they were employed in the factory, the provisions of the Factories Act do not apply to them, there is no dispute that they are employees of a Commercial Establishment within the meaning of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: However, even if the Supervisors and Kamdars were employed in any other kind of work connected with the subject of manufacturing process , unless they were employed in the factory, the provisions of the Factories Act do not apply to them, there is no dispute that they are employees of a Commercial Establishment within the meaning of the Act. The High Court was therefore in error in acquitting the respondents

holdings.reasoning_summary: Connection to manufacturing process under Factories Act s.2(l) requires employment within factory premises; absent that, Shops Act applies.

holdings.text: The High Court was therefore in error in acquitting the respondents of the offences of which they were convicted by the Trial Magistrate.
